title: Understanding the Hess's Law Concept
text: Hess's Law states that the enthalpy change of a chemical reaction is the same, no matter the route taken. This means you can rearrange given reactions to obtain the desired reaction, then sum their enthalpy changes.

title: Identify Target and Given Reactions
text:
Reactions given:
$$1$$. CH₂CO+2O₂→2CO₂+H₂O (ΔH_1=-981.1kJ)
$$2$$. CH₄+2O₂→CO₂+2H₂O (ΔH_2=-802.3kJ)

Target reaction:
2CH₄+2O₂→CH₂CO+3H₂O

Identify if you need to reverse or scale these reactions to obtain the target reaction.

title: Reverse and Scale the Methane Reaction
text:
In order to achieve the target reaction, reverse the burning of methane reaction and adjust the coefficients to match the stoichiometry:

- Reverse CH₄+2O₂→CO₂+2H₂O

Scale it by $$2$$ for stoichiometry.

What is the new reaction and the adjusted enthalpy?

title: Combine Adjusted Reactions Using Hess's Law
text:
Combine the adjusted methane reaction with the burning of ketene reaction:

2(CO₂+2H₂O→CH₄+2O₂) $$\Delta H_3=1604.6kJ$$

CH₂CO+2O₂→2CO₂+H₂O $$\Delta H_1$$ $$=-981.1kJ$$

Add these reactions and their enthalpy changes to derive the target reaction.

title: Final Calculation of Enthalpy Change
text:
The final enthalpy change for the target reaction can now be calculated:

2CH₄+2O₂→CH₂CO+3H₂O

Compute the final enthalpy change.
